name: 1579_B. Shifting Sort
description:
The new generation external memory contains an array of integers a[1 … n] = [a_1, a_2, …, a_n].

This type of memory does not support changing the value of an arbitrary element. Instead, it allows you to cut out any segment of the given array, cyclically shift (rotate) it by any offset and insert it back into the same place.

Technically, each cyclic shift consists of two consecutive actions: 

  1. You may select arbitrary indices l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) as the boundaries of the segment. 
  2. Then you replace the segment a[l … r] with it's cyclic shift to the left by an arbitrary offset d. The concept of a cyclic shift can be also explained by following relations: the sequence [1, 4, 1, 3] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 1 and the sequence [4, 1, 3, 1] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 2. 



For example, if a = [1, \color{blue}{3, 2, 8}, 5], then choosing l = 2, r = 4 and d = 2 yields a segment a[2 … 4] = [3, 2, 8]. This segment is then shifted by the offset d = 2 to the left, and you get a segment [8, 3, 2] which then takes the place of of the original elements of the segment. In the end you get a = [1, \color{blue}{8, 3, 2}, 5].

Sort the given array a using no more than n cyclic shifts of any of its segments. Note that you don't need to minimize the number of cyclic shifts. Any method that requires n or less cyclic shifts will be accepted.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of each test case description contains an integer n (2 ≤ n ≤ 50) — the length of the array. The second line consists of space-separated elements of the array a_i (-10^9 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^9). Elements of array a may repeat and don't have to be unique.

Output

Print t answers to all input test cases. 

The first line of the answer of each test case should contain an integer k (0 ≤ k ≤ n) — the number of actions to sort the array. The next k lines should contain descriptions of the actions formatted as "l r d" (without quotes) where l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) are the boundaries of the segment being shifted, while d (1 ≤ d ≤ r - l) is the offset value. Please remember that only the cyclic shifts to the left are considered so the chosen segment will be shifted by the offset d to the to the left.

Note that you are not required to find the minimum number of cyclic shifts needed for sorting. Any sorting method where the number of shifts does not exceed n will be accepted.

If the given array a is already sorted, one of the possible answers is k = 0 and an empty sequence of cyclic shifts.

If there are several possible answers, you may print any of them.

Example

Input


4
2
2 1
3
1 2 1
4
2 4 1 3
5
2 5 1 4 3


Output


1
1 2 1
1
1 3 2
3
2 4 1
2 3 1
1 3 2
4
2 4 2
1 5 3
1 2 1
1 3 1

Note

Explanation of the fourth data set in the example: 

  1. The segment a[2 … 4] is selected and is shifted to the left by 2: [2, \color{blue}{5, 1, 4}, 3] \longrightarrow [2, \color{blue}{4, 5, 1}, 3] 
  2. The segment a[1 … 5] is then selected and is shifted to the left by 3: [\color{blue}{2, 4, 5, 1, 3}] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 3, 2, 4, 5}] 
  3. After that the segment a[1 … 2] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{1, 3}, 2, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{3, 1}, 2, 4, 5] 
  4. And in the end the segment a[1 … 3] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{3, 1, 2}, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 2, 3}, 4, 5]
prompt:
The new generation external memory consists of an array of integers a[1 … n] = [a_1, a_2, …, a_n].

This type of memory does not support changing the value of an arbitrary element. Instead, it allows you to cut out any segment of the given array, cyclically shift (rotate) it by any offset and insert it back into the same place.

Technically, each cyclic shift consists of two consecutive actions: 

  1. You may select arbitrary indices l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) as the boundaries of the segment. You have the freedom to choose any pair of indices for l and r within this constraint. Selecting these indices will establish the start and end of the segment. This selection will define the segment you can work with.
  2. Then you replace the segment a[l … r] with it's cyclic shift to the left by an arbitrary offset d. The concept of a cyclic shift can be also explained by following relations: the sequence [1, 4, 1, 3] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 1 and the sequence [4, 1, 3, 1] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 2. 

For example, if a = [1, \color{blue}{3, 2, 8}, 5], then choosing l = 2, r = 4 and d = 2 yields a segment a[2 … 4] = [3, 2, 8]. This segment is then shifted by the offset d = 2 to the left, and you get a segment [8, 3, 2] which then takes the place of of the original elements of the segment. In the end you get a = [1, \color{blue}{8, 3, 2}, 5].

Sort the given array a using no more than n cyclic shifts of any of its segments. Note that you don't need to minimize the number of cyclic shifts. Any method that requires n or less cyclic shifts will be accepted. Consider various strategies and optimizations that may help achieve the task efficiently.

Input

Output

Print t answers to all input test cases.

Please remember that only the cyclic shifts to the left are considered so the chosen segment will be shifted by the offset d to the to the left.

Note that you are not required to find the minimum number of cyclic shifts needed for sorting. Any sorting method where the number of shifts does not exceed n will be accepted.

If the given array a is already sorted, one of the possible answers is k = 0 and an empty sequence of cyclic shifts.

If there are several possible answers, you may print any of them.

Example

2 1
3

Output

Note

Explanation of the fourth data set in the example:

  3. After that the segment a[1 … 2] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{1, 3}, 2, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{3, 1}, 2, 4, 5] 
  4. And in the end the segment a[1 … 3] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{3, 1, 2}, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 2, 3}, 4, 5]

completions:
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def cyclic_shift_sort(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    results = []
    
    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        
        # Check if the array is already sorted
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue
        
        # We will perform a simple strategy to sort the array
        # This strategy is not optimal but ensures we use at most n shifts
        for i in range(n - 1):
            # Find the minimum element in the unsorted part of the array
            min_index = i
            for j in range(i + 1, n):
                if array[j] < array[min_index]:
                    min_index = j
            
            # If the minimum element is not at the current position, perform a cyclic shift
            if min_index != i:
                # Perform a cyclic shift from i to min_index
                # The offset is min_index - i
                l = i + 1
                r = min_index + 1
                d = min_index - i
                actions.append((l, r, d))
                
                # Perform the cyclic shift
                segment = array[i:min_index + 1]
                shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                array[i:min_index + 1] = shifted_segment
        
        # Append the result for this test case
        results.append((len(actions), actions))
    
    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        index += 1
        array = list(map(int, data[index:index + n]))
        index += n
        test_cases.append((n, array))
    
    # Call the function
    results = cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases)
    
    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(*action)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing an integer n and a list of integers representing the array.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing an integer k (number of operations) and a list of operations.
        Each operation is represented as a tuple (l, r, d) indicating the segment and offset for the cyclic shift.
    """
    results = []

    for n, a in test_cases:
        operations = []
        
        # Check if the array is already sorted
        if a == sorted(a):
            results.append((0, operations))
            continue

        # Perform cyclic shifts to sort the array
        for i in range(n - 1):
            min_index = i
            for j in range(i + 1, n):
                if a[j] < a[min_index]:
                    min_index = j
            
            if min_index != i:
                # Perform a cyclic shift
                l = i + 1
                r = min_index + 1
                d = r - l
                a = a[:l-1] + a[min_index:r] + a[l-1:min_index] + a[r:]
                operations.append((l, r, d))
        
        results.append((len(operations), operations))

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        a = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, a))

    # Call the function
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(f"{action[0]} {action[1]} {action[2]}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts within the constraints provided.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing an integer n and a list of integers representing the array.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing an integer k (number of shifts) and a list of tuples describing each shift.
    """
    results = []

    for n, a in test_cases:
        actions = []
        if a == sorted(a):
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue

        # Implement a simple strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts
        # This strategy does not aim to minimize the number of shifts but ensures it does not exceed n
        for i in range(n - 1):
            if a[i] > a[i + 1]:
                # Find the segment to shift
                l = i + 1
                r = n
                d = 1
                # Perform the cyclic shift
                segment = a[l - 1:r]
                shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                a[l - 1:r] = shifted_segment
                actions.append((l, r, d))
                if a == sorted(a):
                    break

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        a = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, a))

    # Call the function and get the result
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(f"{action[0]} {action[1]} {action[2]}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts each test case array using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of shifts and a list of shift operations.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        
        # Check if the array is already sorted
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue

        # Implement a simple sorting algorithm using cyclic shifts
        for i in range(n - 1):
            min_index = i
            for j in range(i + 1, n):
                if array[j] < array[min_index]:
                    min_index = j
            
            if min_index != i:
                # Perform a cyclic shift to bring the minimum element to the correct position
                l = i + 1
                r = min_index + 1
                d = r - l
                array[l-1:r] = array[l-1:r][d:] + array[l-1:r][:d]
                actions.append((l, r, d))
        
        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        a = list(map(int, input().split()))

## main.py
from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of shifts and the details of each shift.
    """
    results = []

    for n, a in test_cases:
        if a == sorted(a):
            results.append((0, []))
            continue

        actions = []
        sorted_a = sorted(a)

        # Strategy: Perform cyclic shifts to move elements closer to their sorted positions
        for i in range(n):
            if a[i] != sorted_a[i]:
                # Find the correct position of the current element
                correct_pos = sorted_a.index(a[i])
                if correct_pos > i:
                    # Perform a cyclic shift to move the element to its correct position
                    l = i + 1
                    r = correct_pos + 1
                    d = r - l
                    a[l-1:r] = a[l-1+d:r] + a[l-1:l-1+d]
                    actions.append((l, r, d))

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        a = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, a))

    # Call the function
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(f"{action[0]} {action[1]} {action[2]}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts within the constraints.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of operations and a list of operations.
    """
    results = []

    for n, a in test_cases:
        if a == sorted(a):
            results.append((0, []))
            continue

        actions = []
        sorted_a = sorted(a)

        # We will perform cyclic shifts to sort the array
        for i in range(n):
            if a[i] != sorted_a[i]:
                # Find the segment that needs to be shifted
                l = i + 1
                r = n
                for j in range(i + 1, n):
                    if a[j] == sorted_a[i]:
                        r = j + 1
                        break

                # Perform the cyclic shift
                d = r - l
                a[l-1:r] = a[l-1+d:r] + a[l-1:l-1+d]
                actions.append((l, r, d))

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

def main():
    # Read number of test cases
    t = int(input())

    # Read each test case
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        a = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, a))

    # Call the function
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(action[0], action[1], action[2])

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

import typing

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(
    t: int, 
    test_cases: typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, typing.List[int]]]
) -> typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sort arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of shifts and a list of shift operations.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        
        # Check if the array is already sorted
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, []))
            continue

        # Perform cyclic shifts
        for i in range(n):
            # Find the minimum element in the unsorted part of the array
            min_index = i + array[i:].index(min(array[i:]))
            if min_index != i:
                # Perform a cyclic shift to bring the minimum element to the correct position
                l = i + 1
                r = min_index + 1
                d = r - l
                actions.append((l, r, d))
                # Perform the cyclic shift
                array = array[:i] + array[min_index:min_index+1] + array[i:min_index] + array[min_index+1:]

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

def main():
    """Main function to handle input and output."""
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))

    result = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)
    for k, actions in result:
        print(k)
        for l, r, d in actions:
            print(l, r, d)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

import typing

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(
    t: int, 
    test_cases: typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, typing.List[int]]]
) -> typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sort arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of shifts and a list of shift actions.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, []))
            continue

        actions = []
        sorted_array = sorted(array)

        # Simple strategy to perform cyclic shifts
        for i in range(n):
            if array[i] != sorted_array[i]:
                # Find the segment to shift
                l = i + 1
                r = n
                d = 1

                # Perform the cyclic shift
                segment = array[l-1:r]
                shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                array[l-1:r] = shifted_segment

                actions.append((l, r, d))

                # Check if sorted
                if array == sorted_array:
                    break

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

def main():
    # Read number of test cases
    t = int(input())
    # Read each test case
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))

    # Call the function and print the results
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(f"{action[0]} {action[1]} {action[2]}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

import typing

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(
    t: int, 
    test_cases: typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, typing.List[int]]]
) -> typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sort arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: List of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of actions and a list of actions.
    """
    results = []
    
    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        
        # Check if the array is already sorted
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue
        
        # Perform cyclic shifts to sort the array
        for i in range(n):
            # Find the minimum element in the unsorted part of the array
            min_index = i + min(range(n - i), key=lambda x: array[i + x])
            
            if min_index != i:
                # Perform a cyclic shift to bring the minimum element to the correct position
                l = i + 1
                r = min_index + 1
                d = r - l
                array[l-1:r] = array[l-1:r][d:] + array[l-1:r][:d]
                actions.append((l, r, d))
        
        results.append((len(actions), actions))
    
    return results

def main():
    """Main function to handle input and output."""
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))
    
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)
    
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(*action)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts and returns the number of shifts and their details for each test case.

    Args:
        t: The number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of shifts and a list of shift details for each test case.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        if array == sorted(array):
            # If the array is already sorted, no shifts are needed.
            results.append((0, []))
            continue

        actions = []
        # A simple strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts
        for i in range(n - 1):
            min_index = i
            for j in range(i + 1, n):
                if array[j] < array[min_index]:
                    min_index = j
            if min_index != i:
                # Perform a cyclic shift to bring the minimum element to the correct position
                l = i + 1
                r = min_index + 1
                d = r - l
                array[l-1:r] = array[l-1+d:r] + array[l-1:l-1+d]
                actions.append((l, r, d))

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))

    # Call the function and get the result
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(' '.join(map(str, action)))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

# [core concept]
    'cyclic shift'
    Explanation: A cyclic shift involves rotating a segment of the array to the left by a specified offset, effectively moving elements from the start of the segment to the end.

    'sort the array'
    Explanation: The goal is to rearrange the elements of the array in non-decreasing order using cyclic shifts.

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    'no more than n cyclic shifts'
    Explanation: The task is to sort the array using at most n cyclic shifts, where n is the length of the array. This means we can perform up to n shifts to achieve the sorted order.

# [degree adverb]
    No degree adverb

# [code logic]
1. For each test case, read the length of the array and the array itself.
2. Check if the array is already sorted. If it is, output 0 and no actions.
3. If not sorted, identify segments that can be cyclically shifted to move elements closer to their sorted positions.
4. Perform cyclic shifts on identified segments and keep track of these actions.
5. Ensure that the number of shifts does not exceed n.
6. Output the number of shifts and the details of each shift for each test case.

    Test case with already sorted array:
    Input: [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
    Output: 0
    Explanation: The array is already sorted, so no shifts are needed.

# [core concept]
    'cyclic shift'
    Explanation: A cyclic shift involves rotating a segment of the array to the left by a specified offset. This operation allows rearranging elements within a segment without changing the overall length of the array.

    'segment'
    Explanation: A segment is a contiguous subarray defined by two indices, l and r, where 1 ≤ l < r ≤ n. This segment is the part of the array that can be cyclically shifted.

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    'no more than n'
    Explanation: The number of cyclic shifts performed to sort the array should not exceed the length of the array, n. This means we can perform up to n shifts to achieve the sorted order.

# [degree adverb]
    No degree adverb

# [code logic]
1. For each test case, read the integer n and the array a.
2. Check if the array is already sorted. If it is, output k = 0 and an empty sequence.
3. If not sorted, identify segments that can be cyclically shifted to move elements closer to their sorted positions.
4. Use a loop to perform up to n cyclic shifts:
   - Select indices l and r to define a segment.
   - Choose an offset d to perform a left cyclic shift on the segment.
   - Apply the cyclic shift and update the array.
   - Record the action "l r d".
5. After sorting, output the number of actions k and the list of actions.

    Test case with already sorted array:

We will implement a function that sorts arrays using cyclic shifts. The approach will involve selecting segments of the array and performing cyclic shifts to move elements into their correct positions. We will use Python's list slicing capabilities to perform the cyclic shifts efficiently. The solution will handle multiple test cases and provide output in the specified format.
Please read and understand the following inteperation before coding
# [core concept]
    'cyclic shift'
    Explanation: A cyclic shift involves rotating elements within a specified segment of an array to the left by a given offset. This operation allows rearranging elements without changing their relative order outside the segment.

    'sort using cyclic shifts'
    Explanation: The task is to sort the array by performing cyclic shifts on segments, ensuring the number of shifts does not exceed the length of the array.

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    'no more than n cyclic shifts'
    Explanation: The number of cyclic shifts performed to sort the array should be less than or equal to the length of the array. This constraint ensures efficiency in sorting.

# [degree adverb]
    No degree adverb

# [code logic]
    1. For each test case, read the array and its length.
    2. Check if the array is already sorted; if so, output 0 and no actions.
    3. If not sorted, identify segments that can be cyclically shifted to move elements into their correct positions.
    4. Perform cyclic shifts on identified segments, keeping track of the number of shifts.
    5. Ensure the number of shifts does not exceed the length of the array.
    6. Output the number of shifts and their details for each test case.

# [edge case]
    Test case with already sorted array:
    Input: [1, 2, 3, 4]
    Output: 0
    Explanation: The array is already sorted, so no cyclic shifts are needed.

    Test case with all identical elements:
    Input: [5, 5, 5, 5]
    Output: 0
    Explanation: All elements are identical, so the array is trivially sorted.

    Test case with minimum length:
    Input: [2, 1]
    Output: 1
    Explanation: A single shift is needed to sort the array.

# [extra code for edge case]
    We do not need extra code to handle the edge cases. The original logic can handle arrays that are already sorted or contain identical elements by checking if sorting is necessary before performing any shifts.
examples:
Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of each test case description contains an integer n (2 ≤ n ≤ 50) — the length of the array. The second line consists of space-separated elements of the array a_i (-10^9 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^9). Elements of array a may repeat and don't have to be unique.

Output

Print t answers to all input test cases. 

The first line of the answer of each test case should contain an integer k (0 ≤ k ≤ n) — the number of actions to sort the array. The next k lines should contain descriptions of the actions formatted as "l r d" (without quotes) where l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) are the boundaries of the segment being shifted, while d (1 ≤ d ≤ r - l) is the offset value. Please remember that only the cyclic shifts to the left are considered so the chosen segment will be shifted by the offset d to the to the left.

Note that you are not required to find the minimum number of cyclic shifts needed for sorting. Any sorting method where the number of shifts does not exceed n will be accepted.

If the given array a is already sorted, one of the possible answers is k = 0 and an empty sequence of cyclic shifts.

If there are several possible answers, you may print any of them.

Example

Input


4
2
2 1
3
1 2 1
4
2 4 1 3
5
2 5 1 4 3


Output


1
1 2 1
1
1 3 2
3
2 4 1
2 3 1
1 3 2
4
2 4 2
1 5 3
1 2 1
1 3 1

Note

Explanation of the fourth data set in the example: 

  1. The segment a[2 … 4] is selected and is shifted to the left by 2: [2, \color{blue}{5, 1, 4}, 3] \longrightarrow [2, \color{blue}{4, 5, 1}, 3] 
  2. The segment a[1 … 5] is then selected and is shifted to the left by 3: [\color{blue}{2, 4, 5, 1, 3}] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 3, 2, 4, 5}] 
  3. After that the segment a[1 … 2] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{1, 3}, 2, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{3, 1}, 2, 4, 5] 
  4. And in the end the segment a[1 … 3] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{3, 1, 2}, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 2, 3}, 4, 5]
